s1: This course is the first of three core computer science courses on programming.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: It introduces students to the field of computer science as a discipline for solving problems through computation and provides the foundation for more advanced courses on programming and software development.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Data structures and algorithms, the key concepts at the core of computer science, receive their first treatment in this course. The course addresses both functional and imperative programming paradigms.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: The course covers functional programming in depth, developing the core idea of functions operating on data structures.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Students learn the organization of programming languages using types, how programs are evaluated (reduction), functional composition, recursive functions, algebraic data types, pattern matching, parametric polymorphism, higher-order functions.
s2: Implement basic AI algorithms (e.g., standard search or constraint propagation algorithms).

s1: Students also gain exposure to structural induction and proof, introduction to asymptotic analysis of basic data structures, abstract data types, modules, laziness, and streams.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: The functional paradigm demonstrates elegant solutions to many programming problems.
s2: Implement basic AI algorithms (e.g., standard search or constraint propagation algorithms).

s1: The course also introduces imperative programming as an alternative paradigm to functional programming, highlighting similarities and contrasting differences.
s2: The course also aims to give an overview of the historical, philosophical, and logical foundations of AI.

s1: Students learn the basic ingredients of imperative programs: mutable variables, sequencing, conditionals, iteration, functions, eager evaluation, and side effects.
s2: Implement basic AI algorithms (e.g., standard search or constraint propagation algorithms).

s1: The course also introduces students to standard productivity tools for software development that will be used throughout the course and remainder of the computer science degree.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: These include distributed software revision control systems.
s2: Implement basic AI algorithms (e.g., standard search or constraint propagation algorithms).

s1: The Advanced version of this course covers these topics in more depth, allowing students to deepen their understanding and experience.
s2: The course also aims to give an overview of the historical, philosophical, and logical foundations of AI.

s1: Apply fundamental programming concepts, using a functional programming language, to solve simple problems.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Understand basic types and the benefits of static typing.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Distinguish language definition from implementation, syntax and parsing from semantics and evaluation.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Describe, understand and evolve programs, via documentation, testing, and debugging.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Discuss, use, and apply the fundamentals of data structures, algorithms, and design; create, implement, and debug algorithms for solving simple problems, including recursively, using divide-and-conquer, and via decomposition.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Discuss basic algorithmic analysis for simple algorithms; determine appropriate algorithmic approaches to a problem (brute-force, greedy, divide-and-conquer, recursive backtracking, heuristic, dynamic programming).
s2: Implement basic AI algorithms (e.g., standard search or constraint propagation algorithms).

s1: Describe and apply alternative computational paradigms to simple problems.
s2: Design and perform an empirical evaluation of different algorithms on a problem formalisation, and state the conclusions that the evaluation supports.

s1: Understand the legal context for protection of software as intellectual property.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.
